abstract.para: &sbd; needs a watchdog on each node to ensure that misbehaving nodes are really stopped. Modern systems support a hardware watchdog that needs to be fed by a software component (in this case, the &sbd; daemon). &sbd; feeds the watchdog by regularly writing a service pulse to it. If &sbd; stops feeding the watchdog, the hardware enforces a system restart. This protects against failures of the &sbd; process itself, such as becoming stuck on an I/O error.

important.title: softdog limitations
important.para: If no watchdog matches your hardware, the software watchdog (softdog) can be used for testing purposes. However, the softdog driver assumes that at least one CPU is still running, so if all CPUs are stuck, softdog cannot reboot the system. By contrast, hardware watchdogs work even if all CPUs are stuck. Therefore, softdog is not recommended for clusters in production environments.

important.title: Accessing the watchdog timer
important.para: Some hardware vendors ship systems management software that uses the watchdog for system resets (for example, the HP ASR daemon). If the watchdog is used by &sbd;, disable such software. No other software must access the watchdog timer.
